author: KingZandz 255

text: It's good but Shadow Hearts is supposed to have that creepy,mysterious battle theme that repeatedly sends chills down your spine. It's supposed to be a dark game. Now I'm not emo or whatever,but I do love the storyline of Shadow Hearts one and two. The bgm made you actually feel like you're in a horror movie/crime scene drama. Then it came together all marvelously linking both the first and second game. The good ending of part 2 explains how Alice is alive at the end of the first one good ending. Yuri manages to kill Atman and beat the living or dead shit out of those masks. Now given Yuri's personality,he is more arrogant and laid back in the first game. Even more that pacing to the good ending was loose and left loopholes. Seeing how Yuri's personality flipped when discovering that Alice was about to be killed. He beat down the masks and broke through that door. So in short,part 1 and part 2 was great,it ended in a tragedy in both games really,but towards the end of part 2,Yuri was given another chance to make things right. He was sent back to the beginning of Shadow Hearts one where he knew what he had to do it appeared.
author: Edge Valmond

text: That's the thing I like about shadow hearts. (:) )
author: Zadox reo

text: @Zadox reo Yep, Shadow Hearts was an amazing game. I still remember part one had a boss that looked like the Grudge lol
author: Edge Valmond

text: +Edge Valmond I remember playing Shadow Hearts 1, when I was stuck in that cave running around in circles, not knowing how to get out or what to do, the monsters in that place killed me tho lol, hated that place still till this day!
author: Zadox reo

text: @Zadox reo lol I always make sure I had my team strong since I had no sense in direction, so my next best bet was grinding. I remember for one mask in a replay of the story, I forgot some things, and the Judgment ring I think it was called was invisible. Lucky thing I memorized the Judgment ring and all characters attack point. I even hit perfect a few times. Though I have to say one of the most thrilling battles was the Seraphic Radiance battle. You're only allowed to use Yuri in a two part battle. First against his father and then his fathers fusion form of the Seraphic Radiance. That whole battle I was on the edge, I did not want to start over lol.
author: Edge Valmond

text: +Edge Valmond luckly I have beaten Shadow Hearts 1, but I have not complete the game in 100%, have not collected or cleared everything, I think I cleared the game at 78 or 81% something like that, Shadow Hearts will go down in history as the best dark jrpg games ever.
author: Zadox reo

text: @Zadox reo So true, I recommend using a guide. It makes it a lot easier to follow through. If I remember right, if you pass a certain point without collecting a certain item for the final stage of a fusion, then you cannot initiate the final fusion. You need all fusions in order to fight Seraphic Radiance, which makes sense, you can't go fighting a god when you haven't even conquered the prerequisites. Shadow Hearts will always be on of my favorite games
author: Edge Valmond

text: @YinYang19 -cont- it stands to reason that other cultures, particularly those who practiced those forms of spiritual medium rituals, would have access to similar abilities. With Yuri and Kurando, it was more a sort of Shinto/Taoist-esque practice. Sorry again, just thought that might explain it in case you still wondered or if anyone else had a similar question and happened by here.
author: CyrusGreywolf

text: @YinYang19 I know this is hell of late, and I'm very sorry. But, during Covenant, Rasputin and Nicolai both state that Soul Fusion isn't only practiced by the Harmonixers, as they both made soul pacts with demons that allowed them to fuse. It was somewhat different, but if you consider that Shania comes from the Native American society- which practiced various forms of shamanic 'spirit animal' rituals where people would become on with their totem in a trance-like state- cont.
author: CyrusGreywolf
